results.title: An Exclusive Peek at the Met’s Reimagined Rockefeller Wing

results.title: ‘Freaks and Geeks’ at 25: ‘It Was Slipping Away the Entire Time’
results.abstract: The beloved high-school sitcom debuted in September 1999 and lasted one season. Paul Feig, Judd Apatow and others look back on the show’s birth, death and long afterlife.

multimedia.caption: “Freaks and Geeks” was quickly canceled but it launched many careers and remains revered. With, clockwise from top left, Seth Rogen, Samm Levine, Jason Segel, Martin Starr, James Franco, Linda Cardellini, John Francis Daley and Busy Philipps.

results.title: ‘Saturday Night’ Review: Live TV at Its Mildest
results.abstract: When it debuted 50 years ago, “S.N.L.” was chaotic, rangy, even offensive. But nothing’s wild or crazy in Jason Reitman’s fictional reimagining of its first episode.

results.title: At the Whitney, a Stirring Ailey Tribute Moves Dance to the Edge
results.abstract: Music’s in the air, and there’s painting and sculpture in imaginative variety as an art museum gives rare treatment to an ephemeral medium.

results.title: She Found a Home in Music. Now She’s the Composer for the King.
results.abstract: Errollyn Wallen, a Belize-born artist who has been named master of music by King Charles, discusses music as an escape, confronting racism and living by the sea.
per_facet: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

multimedia.caption: Errollyn Wallen, who has been appointed the Master of the King’s Music, said: “I see the arts and music as the lifeblood of a nation. But we are sadly heading for a world in which adults have no idea how music is made.”
multimedia.copyright: Adama Jalloh for The New York Times

results.title: Rubin Museum’s Tibetan Shrine Will Move to Brooklyn Museum
results.abstract: The collection of art and ritual objects will move to the Brooklyn Museum for six years starting in June after the Rubin closes its building to focus on traveling exhibitions and long-term loans.

multimedia.caption: The Tibetan Buddhist Shrine Room has been one of the most popular installations at the Rubin Museum of Art. The Rubin, which is closing its building, is loaning the shrine to the Brooklyn Museum for six years.
multimedia.copyright: via the Rubin Museum of Art; Photo by Dave De Armas

results.title: Katy Perry’s Latest Album Isn’t as Bad as Her Timing
results.abstract: The pop singer’s latest LP, “143,” has been gleefully panned, but its musical faults aren’t as remarkable as Perry’s failure to read the current cultural moment.

results.title: Nick Gravenites, Mainstay of the San Francisco Rock Scene, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A blues devotee from Chicago, he tasted fame in the late 1960s with the Electric Flag, a band that made its debut at Monterey but proved short-lived.

results.title: Lloyd Macklowe, Leading Purveyor of Art Nouveau, Is Dead at 90

results.title: A Museum Director’s Heirs Lay Claim to His Rembrandts
results.abstract: He ran the Mauritshuis and bequeathed it 25 paintings, but said they must always be on display. Today, only five are on show — so the descendants of his close friend say the artworks should be theirs.

multimedia.caption: The Mauritshuis museum in The Hague is home to masterpieces including Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring” and Carel Fabritius’s “The Goldfinch.”
